Yes. Mother nature allows us to cheat a little because the heat from the lava is transferred into the rock surrounding every volcano. That hot rock stays hot for a long time, continually heated by the nearby lava. So, what we can do is drill holes down into the hot rock to extract that abundant energy in the form of heat. It is called “Hot rock energy” or scientifically: geothermal energy. To get the energy out into a form that can be used in turbines to make electricity, they pump water down into the boreholes. This gets heated and converted to steam, the steam expands in the turbine and cranks the electricity making machine. This is such a clean way of making electricity. Once the steam condenses at the downstream end of the process, the water is collected and recycled back down into the borehole to make more steam. It’s not quite as simple as this, but in principle, this is the science behind getting energy from lava.

We already do in an indirect sort of way. We use the internal heat from the Earths crust to produce geothermal energy. The earth naturally gets hotter the deeper you get, and you don't have to go very deep to reach energy producing temperatures. This is done using drilling rigs. Trying to use actual lava would be very dangerous and unpredictable. Volcanic eruptions are extremely hazardous. Even the pretty gooey ones you see on Hawaii. Only super villains would dare such a thing.

To the extent that the lava contains radioactive / fissile elements. For example, many lavas will contain around 1% of K2O so they will contain a non-trivial amount of K-40, which decays to Ar-40. This releases energy.
Yes. In Iceland 23% of all their energy use is geothermal (hot rocks, so, at base, though not directly, magma/lava). Renewable energy in Iceland - Wikipedia
